properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 30 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 3 to 5 days. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T05:56:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T13:56:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2859984231.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong comeback of the humidity beginning Sunday. The heat will persist until Tuesday. The hottest days will be Monday and Tuesday with humidex values near 40. Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water par day. Follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Limit physical activities; Reduce health risks to young children by cooling them often, hydrating them adequately and reducing their exposure to heat. Plan to visit and check up on loved ones (neighbours, friends and family), especially those who suffer from a loss of autonomy, from a chronic disease or those who live alone, in order to ensure they are cool and not dehydrated. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-27T23:10:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T15:11:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1948863427.2019

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert: Overland Flow Flood Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: A mandatory evacuation order remains in effect for the Hamlet of Marten Beach until further notice.There continues to be a potential for ongoing flooding and hazardous conditions in the Marten Beach area. ### Campers at the Provincial Park and Group Camp may now exit the area through Range Road 65 (Northshore Drive) to the North with access East to Wabasca on Hwy 754 or North to Red Earth on Hwy 88 or West on Hwy 750 through Atikameg and Grouard. The excavator on the bridge will move off the bridge to allow larger campers and trailers to pass for 15 minutes at the top of each hour. A map of the routes can be found on www.mdlsr.ca.
Expires: 2019-08-03T11:26:08-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Municipal District of Lesser Slave River No. 124, 2019-07-27T11:24:04-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-5954
Area: Lesser Slave River #124
properties.Author: Municipal District of Lesser Slave River No. 124

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A thunderstorm just northwest of Timmins will reach the Cochrane area near 3.30 PM. Wind gusts of 90 km/h, torrential downpours giving 20 to 30 mm of rain in under an hour and small hail are possible. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops.
Expires: 2019-07-27T21:29:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T18:51:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4196538479.2019
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 30 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 3 to 5 days. A warm and increasingly humid air mass is settling over Maritimes today and will remain into the middle of next week. Maximum temperatures today have reached or exceeded 30 celsius for much of the province, and Sunday is expected to be similar, with areas of southern and eastern New Brunswick reaching or possibly exceeding 30 degrees. Coastal areas may remain a bit cooler in onshore breezes. Nighttime temperatures tonight into Sunday are expected to range from 17 to 20 degrees, which will not provide much relief from the heat. Humidex values are expected to remain near or slightly below 35 over the weekend. It is likely that the heat will continue into the middle of next week with an increase in humidity on Tuesday and Wednesday, when humidex values could exceed 36. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T10:53:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T18:54:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3803877805.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:04 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of thunderstorms extends from just north of Red Deer to 15 km northwest of Airdrie and is moving eastwards at 50 km/h. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-07-27T22:52:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T20:05:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3779949221.2019

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 35 are expected for the next 2 days. Conditions today and tonight have combined to justify a heat warning. Temperatures today are currently in the 27 to 30 C range and may creep higher later this afternoon. In addition, nighttime lows should not drop below 18 C tonight. For Sunday temperatures should be near 28 inland. After Sunday the warm and humid conditions may persist into the middle of the coming week. Conditions could be slightly cooler on Monday, with temperatures likely falling to 26 to 28 degrees. Nighttime temperatures during this period are expected to be near 18 degrees. Current indications are that warmer conditions with increased humidity could be in store for Tuesday and Wednesday, with humidex values nearing 36. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T09:50:51-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Fog has become patchy as expected. However dense fog is forecast to form again this evening then persist overnight into Sunday morning across the region. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times. Scattered thunderstorms are expected to move eastward across the waters this afternoon and evening. Wind gusts to 40 knots, torrential downpours, and frequent lightning may be associated with some of these storms. ### Poor to very poor visibility may contribute to voyage delays and make marine navigation hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 2:14 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. A line of thunderstorms extending from Little Abitibi Provincial Park to just south of Kapuskasing is moving slowly eastward. Wind gusts near 90 km/h, torrential downpours giving 20 to 30 mm rain in under an hour, and 1 to 2 cm hail are possible. Locations impacted include: Smooth Rock Falls, Greenwater Provincial Park and Little Abitibi Provincial Park. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops.
Expires: 2019-07-27T20:59:14-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 3:18 p.m. EDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing strong wind gusts, pea to dime size hail and heavy rain. A line of thunderstorms extending from near Kesagami Provincial Park across Smooth Rock Falls to just east of Saganash Lake is moving slowly eastward and may reach the communities of Cochrane and Iroquois Falls between 4 and 5 PM. Wind gusts near 90 km/h, torrential downpours giving 20 to 30 mm rain in under an hour, and 1 to 2 cm hail are possible. At this point it appears the thunderstorms will pass by Timmins to the north. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. A cold front may trigger severe thunderstorms with damaging winds and torrential downpours this afternoon and evening. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-07-28T05:59:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T18:07:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1059237291.2019

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot and humid conditions continue this weekend into early next week. Daytime maximum temperatures of 31 degrees are expected along with overnight low temperatures of 20 degrees. There may be brief relief from the heat in some areas on Sunday as showers or thunderstorms are possible. A slightly cooler airmass is expected to arrive on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms are expected to develop over parts of central and eastern Alberta this afternoon. Some of these thunderstorms will have the potential to become severe. The thunderstorm threat will continue into the early evening hours. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T08:01:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T20:13:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3160550387.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms are expected to develop over parts of central and eastern Alberta this afternoon. Some of these thunderstorms will have the potential to become severe. The thunderstorm threat will continue into the early evening hours. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot and humid conditions continue this weekend into early next week. Daytime maximum temperatures of 31 degrees are expected along with overnight low temperatures of 21 degrees. There may be brief relief from the heat on Sunday and again on Monday as showers or thunderstorms are possible both days. A slightly cooler airmass is expected to arrive on Tuesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T12:10:01-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. This severe thunderstorm watch will be in effect until 10:00 PM EDT. ### Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:53 p.m. MDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. This line of thunderstorms extends from just south of Bowden to 10 km west of Crossfield and is moving eastwards at 50 km/h. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2019-07-27T22:52:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T19:54:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3167679875.2019

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wildfire smoke is causing poor air quality and locally reduced visibilities at times. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. For more information please visit Alberta Health Services at www.albertahealthservices.ca/news/air.aspx. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-07-28T09:30:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, Alberta Environment and Parks, Alberta Health, Alberta Health Services, 2019-07-27T17:31:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0468694553.2019

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 29 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 16 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 5 days. A warm and increasingly humid air mass is settling over the Maritimes this weekend and will remain into the middle of next week. Maximum temperatures on Sunday are expected to reach or exceed 29 degrees celsius, especially in the valley and interior regions of southwestern Nova Scotia. Nighttime temperatures tonight into Sunday are expected to remain near 16 degrees except for low lying areas where it will be cooler. Humidex values are expected to remain near or below 35 over the weekend. It is likely that the heat will spread further to the east on Sunday and continue into the middle of next week, as humidity continues to increase. Humidex values could exceed 36 on Tuesday and Wednesday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-28T10:54:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-27T18:55:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1507889688.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and heavy rain. A cold front may trigger severe thunderstorms with damaging winds and torrential downpours this afternoon and evening. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
